awd_titl_txt: I-Corps:  Zero-waste Approach to Reuse Spent Coffee Grounds
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is due to the zero-waste approach to resue spent coffee grounds (SCGs). This technology can potentially result in a more sustainable waste management practice. It can greatly reduce landfill costs for the municipalities and SCG generators. The technology will result in more resources conserved by generating value added materials and reduce the community?s carbon footprint. This I-Corps project will directly benefit the entrepreneurial leaders by allowing them to go out of the laboratory and make real world customer connections. This experience will better equip the PI with the mindset and skills to pursue commercial applications of her future research. This customer discovery process will provide the team with essential information on technology-market fit, thus paving the way of commercialization. This project may greatly promote the adoption of this environmentally friendly technology by the society. 

This I-Corps project is based on laboratory proven technology to reuse the whole parts of SCGs. The SCGs will be separated into two products, the lipid fraction as biofuels and the remaining solids as either biochar or a specialized activated carbon. A direct esterification process is used for lipid extraction, which also enhances the subsequent carbon reuse process with sulfur enrichment. Compared with the solvent extraction process used by others, our patent-pending process is more cost effective, efficient and environmentally friendly. The simplicity and low cost will promote its wide use, and thus effectively divert SCG from landfills and generate value added products that can be used locally.  Customer discovery is essential in understanding the product market fit, which will greatly facilitate technology commercialization.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Project Title: I-Corps: Zero-waste Approach to Reuse Spent Coffee Grounds
PI: Mingming Lu
Awardee: University of Cincinnati Main Campus
Award Number: 1838771
Award Ends:12/31/2019

Brief Result Summary:

Coffee is the second most consumed beverage only next to water. However, up to 91% of coffee ends up as spent coffee grounds (SCGs). Although there are many efforts to reuse  SCGs, SCGs are still mainly landfilled, which is a waste of resources, takes up valuable land, and creates various pollution issues.  

A technology was developed which can use all parts of spent coffee grounds (SCG), the lipid as biofuels and the solids as biochar. Biochar can be used as soil amendments and low cost water pollution material.  Therefore, the overall goal of this I-Corps project is to find product-market fit for a technology. The customer discovery process focused on finding markets for these two products.

An I-Corps team was formed which consisted of the PI, a commercialization expert, and two entrepreneurial leaders, a graduate student and an undergraduate student. The team went to an intensive a seven-week I-Corps curriculum in July-August of 2018. They were trained to identify potential  customers for their technology/product, and also different types of  important influencers along the supply chain. The team conducted 118 interviews (77 face to face) with 103 organizations, which included 9 SCG generators, 3 SCG collectors, 1 SCG processing company, 27 farmers, landowners, parks management staff, 13 garden product carriers, 10 biochar companies, 13 biochar researchers, 13 different garden product carriers and 14 regulatory agencies. The count of organizations excluded people from the same organization and multiple interviews of the same organization.

The team learned that urban farmers (instead of rural farmers), parks landscape managers, green-roof installers, etc. can be  potential customers for the SCG biochar. Urban farmers own much less land comparing with rural farmers. The land needs to be used every year and

need to grow produce with higher values, such as vegetables, ornament plants, etc. instead of potatoes and corn.  Most veggies or fruits tend to prefer  acidic soil conditions, and has more need for nutrient and moisture removal, which our biochar can potentially provide. They are also more conscious about the environment. Although biochar has not been used by many urban farmers, they are potentially more likely to adopt products that are environmentally friendly.

With these findings, we went back to the laboratory to further characterized our SCG biochar. We can produce an acid biochar suitable for many urban farming applications. The biochar can also potentially be used as a low-cost pollutant removal media, which has higher values. 

Intellectual merit: This I-Corps project focused on reuse the whole parts of SCGs. The SCGs will be separated into two products, the lipid fraction as biodiesel and the remaining solids as biochar. SCG reuse will result in landfill diversion, and replenish the urban energy cycle with a clean biofuel, and the food cycle with biochar. Biochar can also better retain water and nutrients, which can result in less water use and fertilizer use.

Broader impact: Zero-waste approach to reuse SCGs, a common food waste in urban communities, promotes sustainable practices. It can greatly reduce landfill costs for municipalities  and generate value added products as energy and materials.

Outcome:

Students trained: 2 graduate students (one female), and 3 undergraduate students (one female) were involved in the project.  The project was used as a senior design project for chemical engineering in 2019 and 2020 school year, which involved a 5-student team for reach year. The first team designed a community scale plant for making biodiesel, and the second team is working on a design for biochar production.

Publications: A conference paper on using biochar for heavy metal removal in water for the  2019 AWMA (Air and Waste Management Association) conference. The result was also presented in a biochar conference in 2019.
